newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian coastguards to patrol Albanian waters.
newsitem.headline: Italian coastguards to patrol Albanian waters.

text.p: Four Italian coastguard vessels left this southeastern Italian port on Thursday to patrol Albanian waters in an attempt to dissuade illegal emigrants from trying to cross the Adriatic.
They will deploy inside Albanian waters off the port of Durres, where four more vessels will join them in the next few days, coastguard officials said.
A similar operation is being planned for the southern Albanian port of Vlore, in the hands of rebels since an armed insurrection erupted in Albania in late February.
The patrols, and aerial surveillance of the narrow Strait of Otranto between Albania and Italy, have been established under a bilateral agreement between the countries.
Italy is leading a multinational force of up to 6,000 troops which began deploying in Albania this week to assist in a relief mission to the impoverished state.

Its eagerness to lead the mission, a major foreign policy test, has been encouraged in part by a desire to stem a flow of illegal Albanian immigrants to Italy since Stalinist rule in the Balkan state collapsed in 1991.
Around 13,000 Albanians arrived in March in a fleet of overcrowded boats.
Albanian officials say as many as 83 Albanians drowned on March 28 when a boat from Vlore collided with an Italian corvette trying to turn the vessel back.

Italian Navy chief of staff Admiral Angelo Mariani said in a message to the departing 48 coastguards on Thursday that their task was "to exercise in depth control of the phenomenon of clandestine immigration".
The coastguards will also seek to halt smuggling from Albania to Italy, which often involves drugs, and help to re-establish normal port activities in Durres and Vlore.
